questions.text: Which type of vitiligo doesn't usually progress in the long term?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Segmental:

  • Segmental vitiligo is present along a segment/dermatome.
  • It develops after birth during childhood.
  • Depigmented macules are seen in particular dermatomes and are unilateral with midline demarcation.
  • These have relatively stable courses and are not amenable to medical treatment; hence, surgical treatment is required.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D:

  • These are non-segmental types of vitiligo.
  • They are not along the segment/dermatome but can be focal and limited to one area.
  • These are autoimmune and have a tendency to progress long-term.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female who had a history of chronic sun exposure presented to the OPD clinic with brownish pigmentation as shown in the image. Which of the following is the diagnosis?

'
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Melasma

Explanation:

This woman with hyperpigmented patches on her cheek and a history of chronic sun exposure most likely has melasma.

Melasma:

  • It is characterized by hyperpigmented macules with scalloped or irregular margins that are darker than the surrounding areas.
  • These patches typically appear on the face, with common locations being the cheeks, forehead, and chin.
  • It is more common in females.
  • Etiologic factors include:
    • Genetic influences, ultraviolet (UV) radiation, pregnancy, hormonal therapies (Ex-OCPs), cosmetics, and phototoxic drugs.
  • Sun protection with broad-spectrum sunscreen with a high SPF, wearing protective clothing, and avoiding prolonged sun exposure aim to prevent further pigmentation.
  • Topical hydroquinone inhibits tyrosinase, an enzyme responsible for pigment production in melanocytes, and is a common depigmenting agent.
    • Triple combination therapy of hydroquinone, retinoid, and corticosteroid is highly effective for melasma.
    • Chemical peels, azelaic acid, and laser therapy are other options.

Freckles (Option B): Freckles (ephelides) are small, light-brown macules that darken with sun exposure and fade in winter. They are more common in fair-skinned individuals and appear in childhood.

Melanoma (Option C): Melanoma presents as an irregularly shaped, rapidly growing pigmented lesion with asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, and possible ulceration. It does not typically present as uniform brown pigmentation.

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) (Option D): BCC commonly appears as a pearly, translucent nodule with telangiectasia, central ulceration, or rolled borders, rather than diffuse pigmentation.

questions.text: A 13-year-old patient presents with the velvety lesion shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acanthosis Nigricans

Explanation:

The presence of velvety, hyperpigmented lesions is characteristic of Acanthosis Nigricans. This condition is caused by hyperkeratosis (thickening of the skin) without an increase in melanocyte or melanin production. It commonly affects intertriginous areas (skin folds such as the neck, axillae, groins, and submammary folds) and is associated with obesity, insulin resistance, hypothyroidism, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), acromegaly, and other metabolic disturbances.

  • Pathogenesis: The condition is linked to increased production of IGF-1 (insulin-like growth factor 1).
  • Types:
    • Benign Acanthosis Nigricans: Associated with diabetes, obesity, or metabolic syndrome.
    • Malignant Acanthosis Nigricans: Rapid onset and linked to visceral malignancies, such as adenocarcinomas of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Velvety, asymptomatic, symmetrical darkening of the skin.
    • Often begins in the neck, axillae, groins, or other intertriginous areas.
    • May lead to the development of skin tags in affected regions.
  • The presence of these lesions is a cutaneous marker for underlying metabolic abnormalities and insulin resistance.
  • Treatment involves addressing the underlying condition with lifestyle modifications and, if necessary, topical treatments like keratolytics or retinoids.

Tinea Versicolor (Option B)

  • Caused by a fungal infection (Malassezia species).
  • Presents as hypopigmented or hyperpigmented scaly macules/patches, not velvety lesions.
  • Typically has a scaly appearance, especially after sun exposure.

Seborrheic Keratosis (Option C)

  • A benign skin lesion that appears as well-demarcated, warty, or "stuck-on" plaques.
  • Common in older adults.
  • Does not have the velvety texture characteristic of Acanthosis Nigricans.

Atopic Dermatitis (Option D)

  • Also known as eczema, it appears as dry, itchy, scaly, and inflamed patches of skin.
  • Typically affects flexural surfaces (e.g., behind knees, elbows) rather than intertriginous areas.
  • Velvety hyperpigmented patches are not a feature of atopic dermatitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with small, depigmented lesions which have been there for over 2 years now as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitiligo

Explanation:

  • The image shows depigmented patches on the arm, which are characteristic of Vitiligo.

Vitiligo:

  • Vitiligo is an acquired pigmentation disorder featuring well-defined depigmented macules on the skin.
  • Biopsies show epidermal melanocyte loss. Lesions may be localized or generalized, coalescing into large depigmented areas.
  • Wood's lamp, emitting ultraviolet A (UV-A) light, aids in diagnosis by revealing bright blue-white fluorescence with sharply demarcated borders in vitiligo lesions, particularly in individuals with pale skin.

Melasma (Option A):

  • Melasma presents as hyperpigmented (brownish) patches, often on sun-exposed areas like the face.
  • It is associated with pregnancy, oral contraceptive use, and sun exposure.

Psoriasis (Option C):

  • Psoriasis features erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales, usually on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees.
  • It does not cause depigmentation.

Dermatitis Herpetiformis (Option D):

  • This is a chronic, intensely pruritic vesicular disease associated with celiac disease.
  • It presents as grouped vesicles and papules rather than depigmented patches.

questions.text: A young girl presents with leukotriosis and lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Segmental vitiligo

 

Explanation:

The presence of leukotrichia (white hair) along with depigmented patches suggests vitiligo, as leukotrichia is uncommon in congenital disorders like piebaldism or nevus depigmentosus.

Segmental vitiligo affects one side of the body and follows a dermatomal or unilateral pattern.

It occurs early in life, progresses rapidly, and then stabilises, unlike generalised vitiligo, which progresses over time.

 

Focal Vitiligo (Option A) is incorrect because focal vitiligo presents as small, isolated patches but does not follow a segmental/dermatomal distribution. It often progresses into generalised vitiligo, unlike segmental vitiligo, which remains localized.

Piebaldism (Option C) is incorrect because it is a congenital disorder (present from birth) due to c-KIT gene mutations. Typically associated with a white forelock (poliosis) and symmetrical patches, not segmental.

Nevus Depigmentosus (Option D) is incorrect because it is a stable hypopigmented patch present from birth. Unlike vitiligo, it does not progress or show leukotrichia.

questions.text: What is the purpose of using Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Preservative

  • Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is commonly used as a preservative in cosmetics. It helps prevent the growth of bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms in cosmetic products, thereby extending their shelf life and maintaining their safety and efficacy.

Incorrect Options:

Surfactant (Option A): Surfactants are commonly used in cosmetic products to enhance foaming, cleansing, and emulsifying properties. While surfactants are frequently used in cosmetics, methylisothiazolinone is not primarily used as a surfactant.

Humectant (Option B): Humectants are commonly used in skincare and cosmetic products to prevent dryness and maintain moisture balance. Methylisothiazolinone is not typically used as a humectant.

Emulsifier (Option C): Emulsifiers are commonly used in cosmetic formulations to create stable emulsions, such as creams and lotions. Methylisothiazolinone is not primarily used as an emulsifier.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with a non-progressive hypopigmented lesion on the trunk. On Wood’s lamp examination, there is white accentuation. Diasoscopy is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nevus depigmentosus

Explanation:

  • Nevus depigmentosus is a congenital, stable, non-progressive hypopigmented macule or patch, present from early life.
  • Lesion is usually solitary, well-defined, and does not spread over time.
  • Wood’s lamp shows an off-white accentuation (less bright than vitiligo).
  • Diascopy is negative because the hypopigmentation is due to reduced melanin, not vascular changes.
  • No sensory loss or scaling is present.
  • Management is generally reassurance; no effective repigmentation treatment is required unless for cosmetic concerns.

Vitiligo (Option A): An acquired progressive depigmentation with complete loss of melanin; Wood’s lamp shows bright chalk-white fluorescence; lesions tend to enlarge over time.
 

Nevus anemicus (Option C): A vascular anomaly where skin appears pale due to localized increased vasoconstriction; diascopy causes the lesion to blend with surrounding skin (positive diascopy), unlike nevus depigmentosus.
 

Indeterminate leprosy (Option D): Hypopigmented patch with impaired sensation and possible nerve thickening; would not be stable for years without progression, and diagnosis requires sensory loss or skin smear evidence.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a pregnant woman of age 30 who visits the dermatology outpatient department (OPD) with the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D Chloasma

  • A common skin condition that can occur during pregnancy is chloasma, also known as the "mask of pregnancy." The appearance of brownish or grayish patches on the face, particularly on the cheeks, nose, forehead, and upper lip, is a hallmark of this condition. Chloasma is brought on by hormonal changes during pregnancy, particularly an increase in estrogen and progesterone levels, both of which can encourage the skin to produce more melanin.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a. Systemic lupus erythematosus: Lupus, also known as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect a variety of body organs and tissues. It is characterized by the production of autoantibodies that damage and inflame the body's own tissues and cells. SLE is more common in ladies, and side effects can shift generally from one individual to another, contingent upon which organs and tissues are impacted.
  • Option b. Viral infection: The given image is not of viral infection
  • Option c. Rosacea: Rosacea is a long-term condition of the skin that mostly affects the face and causes redness, flushing, and blood vessels to show up. It can likewise cause pimple-like knocks and thickened skin on the cheeks, and brow. Rosacea typically affects fair-skinned adults over the age of 30 who have a family history of the condition.

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is used to identify the condition depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Wood's light assessment is a symptomatic test utilized in dermatology to assist with recognizing different skin conditions, including contagious contaminations, bacterial diseases, and color problems like vitiligo. Dermatologists are able to observe subtle changes in the skin that might not be apparent under normal lighting conditions thanks to the use of ultraviolet light to highlight fluorescent substances in the skin.
  • The patient's skin is first cleansed, and any cosmetics or lotions are removed during a Wood's lamp examination. The dermatologist applies the UV light from Wood's lamp to the patient's skin in a room that is darkened. The fluorescent substances in the skin mirror the light, making the skin seem an alternate tone, it is inspected to rely upon the condition. For instance, fungal infections can have a yellow-green appearance, while pigment disorders can have a white or blue-green appearance.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a. Culture: Microorganisms like bacteria, viruses, and fungi can be identified and grown from a sample of tissue or bodily fluid with the help of a culture test in the laboratory. Cultures are frequently utilized in dermatology to diagnose fungal or bacterial skin infections like cellulitis, impetigo, or fungal skin infections.
  • Option c. Gram staining: A laboratory test known as "gram staining" is used to determine the kind of bacteria that is present in a sample of bodily fluid or tissue. In dermatology, it is frequently used to diagnose bacterial skin infections like folliculitis, cellulitis, and impetigo.
  • Option d. Patch test: A diagnostic test known as patch testing is used to pinpoint the substances or allergens that may be triggering allergic contact dermatitis. When the skin comes into contact with a substance that the immune system perceives as foreign and reacts against, this type of dermatitis is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A : Malignant melanoma

Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that develops from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing the pigment melanin. It often appears as an asymmetrical, irregularly bordered, and multi-colored lesion on the skin. The image given is likely to be malignant melanoma as it is consistent with the ABCDE rule that is:

  • A - Asymmetry: Look for any irregularity in shape. Melanomas often have an asymmetrical shape, meaning one half doesn't match the other half.
  • B - Border: Check the edges of the lesion. Melanomas tend to have uneven, ragged, or blurred borders, unlike benign moles that typically have smooth, well-defined borders.
  • C - Color: Examine the color of the lesion. Melanomas may display various shades of brown, black, blue, red, or white within the same lesion. Uneven distribution or changes in color should raise concerns.
  • D - Diameter: Consider the size of the lesion. While melanomas can be small, they are typically larger than benign moles. Any mole or lesion larger than 6 millimeters (about the size of a pencil eraser) should be examined by a healthcare professional.
  • E - Evolution: Monitor the evolution or changes in the lesion over time. Melanomas often undergo changes in size, shape, color, or elevation. Rapid or significant changes should be evaluated promptly.

Incorrect option

Option B : BCC - Also known as Basal cell carcinoma this type of cancer is the most common of all the skin cancers that occur. Generally, this occurs when DNA gets damaged due to exposure to ultraviolet rays and thus results in the formation of carcinomatous cells on the basal cell of the skin.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma - The squamous cell makes up the upper and middle layers of the skin and this type of carcinoma is the most common as it occurs in the squamous cell. Being aggressive it gets widespread in a very short period.

Option D: Nevus - Also known as moles, these are commonly pigmented skin lesions found in adults. Generally, these pigmented skin lesions are formed due to the formation of clusters of melanocytes (pigment-forming cells).

questions.text: Patient with a history of severe sunburn after only a few minutes exposure in the sun (photosensitivity) he noticed freckling in sun-exposed areas, dry skin, and changes in skin pigmentation. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Xeroderma Pigmentosa

 

Explanation:

 

The image and clinical description are classic for Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)—a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterised by extreme sensitivity to UV radiation due to defective DNA repair mechanisms.

Feature Description
Photosensitivity Severe sunburns after minimal UV exposure
Skin pigmentation Early onset of freckling, hypo- and hyperpigmented macules
Skin atrophy Dry, parchment-like skin
Ocular involvement Photophobia, conjunctivitis, corneal opacities, and lid changes
Neurological symptoms May include sensorineural deafness, ataxia, and intellectual disability
Cancer risk Markedly increased risk of basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma at a young age

 

Bloom syndrome (Option B): It is an inherited condition in which the stature of the person is shorter than the average, has a narrow face, and has skin rashes all over. In these people, there is a very high increased chance of cancer to occur.

Warts (Option C): Caused by human papillomavirus, it is characterized by rough and uneven bumps on the skin mostly on the hands, face, and feet. It is a non-cancerous growth occurring mostly in people who do have a weak immune system or people with an autoimmune disease.

Melanocytic nevus (Option D): Generally, a non-cancerous condition is caused by melanocytes ( pigment-producing cells). These are also called moles.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acanthosis nigrican:

  • Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by dark, thickened, and velvety patches of skin. It commonly affects areas such as the neck, armpits, groin, and skin folds.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray brown velvety plaques seen over flexure areas( back of neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist,groin).

Incorrect Options:

Option a - Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is a rare autoimmune disease characterized by muscle weakness and skin rash. The skin rash in dermatomyositis typically appears as a heliotrope rash on the upper eyelids and a Gottron's papules rash on the knuckles, elbows, or knees. It is not represented by the image given.

Option c - Pityriasis rotunda: Pityriasis rotunda is a rare skin disorder characterized by round, scaly patches on the skin. These patches are typically lighter or darker than the surrounding skin and may appear on the trunk, arms, or legs. It is not represented by the image given.

Option d - Melasma: Melasma is a common skin condition characterized by the development of brown or gray-brown patches on the face, particularly on areas exposed to the sun, such as the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. It is not represented by the image given.

Correct Answer: D) Becker’s nevus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a large, irregular, hyperpigmented patch with increased hair growth (hypertrichosis) over the upper trunk/shoulder of a young male — typical of Becker’s nevus.

 

Feature Description
Onset Typically appears during adolescence
Site Commonly over the shoulder, upper back, or chest
Appearance Hyperpigmented, irregular patch
Hair growth Hypertrichosis often develops over the lesion
Gender More common in males
Hormonal link May be associated with androgen sensitivity (increased at puberty)
Malignancy No malignant potential

 

Mongolian spot (Option A): Blue-grey patch usually seen over the sacral area in infants; fades with age.

Nevus of Ito (Option B): Bluish-grey pigmentation in the supraclavicular or shoulder area, often unilateral, but lacks hypertrichosis.

Congenital melanocytic nevus (Option C): Present at birth, usually darker and may be nodular; typically not associated with Becker’s distribution pattern.

questions.text: What is the treatment used for vitiligo among the options listed below?
questions.solution:
Correct option C

  • Vitiligo is a skin condition characterized by the loss of pigmentation in certain areas, resulting in white patches on the skin. Various treatment modalities are available for vitiligo, and the choice depends on factors such as the extent of the condition and patient preferences. Psoralen PUVA (Psoralen plus Ultraviolet A) therapy is a commonly used treatment option. Psoralen is a medication that sensitizes the skin to UVA light, and PUVA involves the combination of psoralen ingestion or topical application followed by exposure to UVA light. This treatment helps stimulate repigmentation of the white patches in vitiligo.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Retinoids are a class of medications derived from vitamin A and are used in various dermatological conditions but are not a primary treatment for vitiligo.

Option B: Systemic steroids may be used in some cases of vitiligo, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

Option D: Nd-YAG laser is a type of laser used in dermatology for various purposes but is not the primary treatment for vitiligo.
